x10.mongo.yak
Class YakMap

x10.lang.Any
  java.util.AbstractMap
      java.util.HashMap
          java.util.LinkedHashMap
              org.bson.BasicBSONObject
                  x10.mongo.yak.YakMap
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Map
public class YakMap
extends org.bson.BasicBSONObject
implements com.mongodb.DBObject

A Mongo-specific BSON object, presenting a good X10 interface. In particular, it has operators and methods for adding and retrieving fields: Here's a way to make the object {"a":1, "b":2, "c":3} 

      val y = YakUtil.it();
      val m : YakMap = 
        y -<"a">- 1
          -<"b">- 2
          -<"c">- 3

YakMaps have interfaces to construct queries and modifier objects. For example, the YakMap to build the query to see if a is 1 and b is even can be built as 

   (new YakMap()).eq("a",1).mod("b",2,0)
Or, if you have the suggested binding val y = YakUtil.it(), as 
   y.eq("a",1).mod("b",2,0)

Similarly, a modifier to increment x by 1 can be built by 

   y.inc("x", 1)
And one to increment x by 1 and y by 2 by: 
   y.inc("x",1).inc("y",2)

In particular you don't need to remember that it's {x: {"$lt":3}} to see if x is less than three, but {"$inc": {x:1}} to increment x by one.

operator-<

public LoadedYakMap operator-<(x10.lang.String s)
Declaration: operator-<(s:x10.lang.String): x10.mongo.yak.LoadedYakMap{self.yakMap==this(:x10.mongo.yak.YakMap), self.newIndex==s}.
The idiom ym -<"a">- 1 -<"b">- 2 adds new entries at "a" and "b" to this.
The  -< operator itself does not modify this.
ym -< k constructs a new object, referring to both ym and k, whose
purpose in existence is to accept a  >- v operation and add the mapping k,v to ym.
Note that, the combination
ym -<"a">- 1 does modify ym.

operator/


public YakMap operator/(x10.lang.String key)




Obtain an element of this which is itself a map.
If ym is {"a": {"b": {"c":1}, "d":2}, "3":3}, 
ym / "a"  is {"b": {"c":1}, "d":2},
and ym / "a" / "b" is {"c":1}.





















operator()


public x10.lang.Any operator()(x10.lang.String key)




Subscripting a YakMap retrieves its elements, as Anys.
If you know what sort of value to expect, a more specific operation will
retrieve it with the right type: ym/"a" for a subobject,
ya.int("b") for an integer,
ya.long("c") for a long,
ya.bool("d") for a boolean,
ya.float("d") for a float,
ya.double("d") for a double,
ya.str("e") for a string.





















operator+


public YakMap operator+(YakMap that)




Modify this by adding all the elements of that (except _id) and return the joined map.
In general in X10, operators should not modify their operands.  This violates that general design principle.
This operation is intended for idioms like
a + (y -<"b">-1)

fieldIs


public YakMap fieldIs(x10.lang.String aa,
                      x10.lang.String bb,
                      x10.lang.Any cc)




Adds to this a field {aa: {bb:cc}}, except in certain cases.
When aa is a mutation operator (like "$inc") and there's already
a field named aa, this combines the values of that field.
e.g. applying fieldIs("$inc", "b", 2) to {$inc: {a:1}}
results in {$inc: {a:1, b:2}}, that is, a modifier which will increment
both a and b by the right amount.


Generally it is better to use specific operations, like inc("a",1), to
produce modifiers and queries.











Parameters:
aa - 
bb - 
cc -

exists


public YakMap exists(x10.lang.String fieldName,
                     x10.lang.Any v)




Add to this a query asking whether the subject has a field named fieldName.
foo.exists("a", true) returns true if there is a field named "a".
foo.exists("a", false) returns true if there is not a field named "a".











Parameters:
fieldName - Name of field being compared
v - Value to return if a field named fieldName is there.
See Also:
http://api.mongodb.org/wiki/current/Advanced%20Queries.html

public YakMap exists(x10.lang.String fieldName)




Add to this a query asking whether a field named fieldName exists.
Equivalent to foo.exists(fieldName, true).











Parameters:
fieldName - Name of field being compared
v - Value it is being compared to.
See Also:
http://api.mongodb.org/wiki/current/Advanced%20Queries.html

mod


public YakMap mod(x10.lang.String fieldName,
                  x10.lang.Long divisor,
                  x10.lang.Long remainder)




Add to this a query asking whether a field named fieldName has value congruent to remainder modulo divisor.
For example, foo.mod("a", 2, 0) selects values with an even "a" field.











Parameters:
fieldName - Name of field being compared
divisor - The divisor
remainder - The remainder for which the query answers true.
See Also:
http://api.mongodb.org/wiki/current/Advanced%20Queries.html

operator|


public YakMap operator|(YakMap that)




a | b returns a YakMap which matches objects matched by either a or b.
This constructs or modifies an $or query.
In particular, the object returned might be a modified version of this (if this already has an
and is a new object if not.











See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Advanced+Queries#AdvancedQueries-%24or

Declaration: x10$mongo$yak$YakMap$$x10$mongo$yak$YakMap$this(): x10.mongo.yak.YakMap{self==this(:x10.mongo.yak.YakMap)}.
A Mongo-specific BSON object, presenting a good X10 interface.
In particular, it has operators and methods for adding and retrieving fields:
Here's a way to make the object {"a":1, "b":2, "c":3}
   
      val y = YakUtil.it();
      val m : YakMap = 
        y -<"a">- 1
          -<"b">- 2
          -<"c">- 3
   

   

   YakMaps have interfaces to construct queries and modifier objects.  For example, 
   the YakMap to build the query to see if a is 1 and b is even can be built
   as 
   
   (new YakMap()).eq("a",1).mod("b",2,0)
   

   Or, if you have the suggested binding val y = YakUtil.it(), as 
   
   y.eq("a",1).mod("b",2,0)
   

   

   Similarly, a modifier to increment x by 1 can be built by
   
   y.inc("x", 1)
   

   And one to increment x by 1 and y by 2 by: 
   
   y.inc("x",1).inc("y",2)
   

   
   

   In particular you don't need to remember that it's {x: {"$lt":3}} to see if 
   x is less than three, 
   but {"$inc": {x:1}} to increment x by one.
